abstracts.cdata!:
The Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper
            (PRSP) is explicitly defined within the vision of the New
            Economic Partnership for African Development (NEPAD) and
            includes the following objectives: (i) good governance,
            including peace-building and conflict prevention; (ii)
            decentralization and economic development in rural areas;
            (iii) development of basic infrastructure; (iv) promotion of
            human capital and skills in support of private sector
            development; (v) capacity building through the use of new
            information technologies; (vi) promotion of regional
            integration and international cooperation; (vii) protecting
            environment and managing durable resources; and (viii)
            protection of vulnerable groups by improving their
            productive capacity and reducing gender disparities. Within
            these broad orientations, the PRSP has four pillars: (i)
            wealth creation through economic reform and private sector
            development; (ii) capacity building and development of basic
            social services; (iii) improving living condition of
            vulnerable groups; and (iv) implementation of the strategy
            and monitoring of its outcomes. As noted in the joint staff
            IMF/World Bank assessment (December 2002), the PRSP suffered
            from some shortcomings, which the authorities intended to
            address during the first years of strategy implementation.
            Among them, it was found that the Government's plans to
            implement the Poverty Reduction Strategy (PRS) were not
            spelled out in sufficient details, notably with regard to a
            fiscal decentralization strategy that would assure better
            public services. The poverty diagnostic did not benefit from
            a complete analysis of the new household survey data, and
            the impact of the specific measures on the well-being of the
            poor was not analyzed in detail.
